To induce the numerous Correspondents
Of the Saturday Evening Post aud others to
furnish original essays and metrical compo-
sitions particularly calculated to enrich the
columns Of the Casket for 1927, the publish
crs have been induced 10 oFcrthe following
rewards.


/. The Caskct for 1926, 1927 and 1923
embellished with numerous engravlngs, and
handsomely bound in rich extra binding,
for the best Essay, in prose, OF moderate
length


.. The Casket for three years, COM
mencing with the volume just finished,
bound in the same superb manner, for the
best American tale, of moderate length.


3. The Caskct for three years, commenc.
ing as above. bound in superb STYLE for the
best Biography of American character, male
or female


a. The Casket for years. or years
subscription to the Saturday Evening Post,
for the 5est metrical composition, not ex-
ceeding sixty lines.
One years subscription to the Casket,
for 1927, will be awarded to each of the Sc.
co'ld best articles in either OF the above de-
partmcnts.


The articles must be addressed to .4tkm-
son u .flerander, Philadelphia, post pad,
and handed in by the first of March next,
when they will undergo the inspection Of
three Literary gentlemen Of this city. and
the awards be distributed with fairness and
impartiality.

The priest vas now called forward to per-
torn another important ceremony. low
table was placed near the nuptal taper =
it was covered with white cloth or napkin,
and the priest sat down at one end, attended
by another Armenian who was not priest,
to say responses. He took out OF his bosom
a small cruci6x, and waving it several times
in the air over the table, uttered henedic-
ton; he then began prayer, and conciuoed
with psalm, accompanied by his assistant
in very dissonant and nasal tone. When
the psalm was over, we were very curious to
see what was under the cloth. 1t was lifted
slowly up, and large rich shawl appeared
on the table, which was Immediately taken
and tremendously wrapped round the pride.
This was considered one of the most lmpor-
tant parts OF the ceremony, and called bless
ing the nuptial. Wenow took our leave and
were invited to come again on the morrow,
when the bride was to be conveyed to the
bridegroom, who was all this time at Gala
to, a distant part of the town, & never SUIT
fered to approach the house. The next day
the lady was led down in the same dress she
wore the day before, and i'll addition to the
ample veil, the eonsecrated shawl was
wrapped round her in such way as abso-
lutely to envelope her


All aruba or Turkish coach drawn by buff
faoes. was waiting at the door; this consist
ed of long platform of boards laid upon 4
wheels, and surmounted with gaudy cano-
py Of wood, carved and gilt. Into this the
bride was lifted, wrapped up, like a child in
swaddling clothes going to be christened.-


Her female friends, including the priests
wife. to the number of ten or twelve. sat
round her,-so as effectualy to conceal her
person. The nuptial candle was borne on
the shoulder of a boy who walked before ;
and in this way the procession slowly moved
to Galato, to the house of her husband. when
for the first time, he was permitted to see
her face. The final marriage ceremony did
not take place till three days after, at which
no strangers We're admitted.o

DEFEAT OF THE BRAZlLIANS.


A letter from the Coast of Brazil has lust
reached us, which contains information I'M
pleasant to the cause of the Emperor. 1t is
dated Santos September 26tlf, and to this ef-
feet:


"There has been a serious conflict between
the Bucnos Avrean troops, and the Brazil
ians, near Montevideo. in which the latter
we're defeated with the loss, it is here cur
rentIy reported, of seventeen hundred pris-
oners, the number of killed and wounded not
mentioned; but, as the contest is supposed
to have been a sangunary one, the loss
must have been excessive.


General .Ilparcz is marching with a
sufficient army for RIO Grande, and the i'm
preston prevails among several well inform
ed and intelligent political men, intimately
acquainted with the defences of the country,
and the disposable force under the Brazil
ians, that the Province will be abandoned
to the Bnenos Ayreans without much oppo-
sition. Should this event take place, | APP
prehend that our Brazilian friends will intl
some difficulty about jerked BERT, in addition
to their other troubles, as it is At that place
they obtain their principal supply, and the
Buenos Ayreans have determined, as mat
ter Of policy, to suspend the preparation of
peer, ana ucVCte tnelr entire energies TO the
successful prosecution of the war.


"There is now no doubt that Admiral
Brown, of whose exploits and unexampled
bravery you must have heard frequently,
has taken command of the Chilian Squadron,
and is daily, might more properly say
hourly looked for on the Coast. AS this
place lies so conveniently to the mouth OF
of the LA Plata, and affords good harbour
and facilities for operations against the Bra
zllians, Admiral Brown will in all probabili-
ty make his first demonstration here. It's
possession is a matter Of the first Importance
to Buenos Ayres, should her Military views
extend really to the occupation of Ric
Grande, and its loss to Brazil, could only be
felt once, and that forever"


"Santos may bc considered point d d'appui
OF much interest, and whether the Brazil.
ians held it in this estimation or not, ] am
uncertain; but of one thing / feel pretty
confident that were it in the hands of Brown


it's Importance to the trade and military de-
signs of Brazil would be most strikingly ex.
emplihed."


The United States ships BrQndy4pine ant

these two vessels sailed SO we'll togethe
that an hour was not lost in the whole ru,

The following description which Capt W.
gives of his situation when entangled IN the
ice, presents an interesting and 1eaftui
picture of the perils OF polar Navigation.
The two vessels under his command the one
a brig. the other cutter, SAILING south from
the Falkland Islands in November, became
completely surrounded with Az ice islands,
from which there was no esress


ain the morning of the 18th we had clos
ed with large ice island, and IN spite OF
all our cndeavors to avoid it, we Continued
approaching. At 10 o'clock it was within
two ships length, and from its peculiar
shape threatened TO overwhelm us; tor the
upper part OF the side nearest TO us, which
was about 1870 feet high, projected SO much
as would have admitted the briggs mast COM
ing in contract with it underneath, and TINS
overhangns part was cracked from the top
down TO the water line. From both vessels
being unavoidably together, both were ike
ly to suffer by the same accident AN our
attempts to hcave the vessels out OF the
course of this danger was in vain, out they
had the good effect of occupying the crews
and thus Withdrawing their ATTENTION from
their perilous situation. Within half All hour
had the appalling sight OF the oVerhalsins
mass Immediately over the quater oecK,
with the fearful sensation that, it our mast
came in contact with it, the projecting part
would fall upon us and sink both vessels.
Our escape was caused solely by our having
large floe piece of ice between us and the
ice island. which prevented our mast from
touching it. The packed ice separated to
each side. and we passed round the north
corner. The rolling of this island In its
passage had produced slackness in the 9TH
er ice, of which was determined TO take
advantage for returning, and so cast oil the
cutter" In this manner the vessels escap-
ed the danger.


The following, translated from French
work by correspondent OF the Charicston
Courier, is an excellent satire upon the pleas
ures Of the appetite.


PIGS EARS.


The Sage who enlightens the world and
devotes his days and nights to the improve
ment OF mankind, dies frequently OF want, IN
an obscure garret-while vile buftoons, who
currupt manners, and the dangerous Cate
rers tor the glutton, are enriched, caressed
and honored. Such was the cook of Marx
Antony, who became Governor OF city, tor
having roasted a young wild boar. to suit
the taste of that incorporate General. Such
was he, who prepared for Charles the 5th,
.io lEo tn m


This famous monarch, after the fatgues
Of the chase, near Valladolid, went to dine
with neighboring Lord, Having been APP
prised of the intended courtesy of his sove
reign, the host studied to have prepared fol
him, a repast equally splendid and singular
When the Prince had dined, he praised We.
~ much the meats and avowed frankly
that the greatest part of them were perfect
ly new to him. The Nobleman who hat
entertained the Spanish King, replied tina
the animals that had supplied the feast wer,
not only very rare, but that they were al
still alive. He then took the Monarch int
neighboring apartment, and pointed out tt
him, in large pasture, the rare birds which
he had been eating. This was a troup O
pigs without ears and without tails; ans
these tails and ears, with the aid of potatoes
reduced to -four, had been dressed with 81
much art that they resembled fowls, venison
turbot, salmon, carp, eels, and almes, every
thing.


The Emperor relished particularly tn,
tails of the pigs, without ears, which he tool
to be the pike and eel of Tartary-indeed
he was so satisfied with this strange repast
that he complimented the cook in person
upon his profound skill in the art OF sauce
and frica,ees. The king did not confne hi
r.. y 30
the cook with tract Of land; thus his disl
of pigs ears and tails enabled him to live th
rest of his life in secure abundance, muel
happier than the grandee of Spain, who's
kitchen fire he had kindled wish such shin
ing success.

let her proceed to Buffalo, invite her friends.
purchase some articles Of clothing, for her
self and him. and return. TO bring his

Cotton 17anufacturc.-It is stated by Mr..
Rush in his report, that the cotton manu-
factories of the United States work up fuli
one fourth part OF the whole crop OF raw
cotton raised in the Southern and Western
States. As this statement is founded on da-
ta that cannot deceive, we may take It with
an unusual degree of certainty. OF all the
statistical facts which lately have come un-
der our observation, we must be permitted
to say this is the most gratifying. Only
let us look back upon our internal industry
for the last 10 years. Iu 1916 we were but
in the commencement. but now our cotton
fabrics can compete with the English. If,
in the short space OF ten years, we have ris-
en- to the consumption of Of our whole raw
cotton crop, what may we not expect from
the succeeding ten? When did nation
possess such prospect as the United States?
In very few years, the whole cotton crop
of the South will be worked up at the North
and East One portion of the country will
supply the other with raw productions, and
that in return with manufactured. Within
the limits of the Republic we have every
variety Of soil and climate. We can pro-
duce every thing within ourselves tits this
peculiar character osthe country that will
become the great bend Of union. A recipro-
cation OF benefits will unite the South, the
West. and the East, in one feeling and one
interest. We shall then be beyond the com.
mercial vicissitudes of Europe. Our depen-
lence for every manufacture will be placed
OH our own artisans. This happy period is
fast approaching, and neither the arts of for
eign or secret enemies can prevent its ac.
complishment.


The National Journal announces that the
Convention between the United States and
England. making provision for compensating
the owners Of fprivate property taken from
the United States after the close Of the late
war with Great Britain, has been ratified
by the President and Senate. The prompt
ness with which this Convention was decid-
ed on in the Senate, confirms the opinion
that it provides for an ample restitution to
those Of our citizens whose property had
been taken from them subsequent to the
war, and that it does them justice, and will
give satisfaction to all the claimants.

| IT is calculated that more than one hun
dred and seventy volcanoes are at present
in activity on this land, and there is reason
to believe that there are at least as many
and probably greater number beneath the
sea- Captain King in his late survey of
Australasia, sailed along continued line OF
Coral Ttel IOr seven nunureu mNeS, IAlcr-
ruptsd only by few intervals not exceed
ing thirty miles. These reefs stretch from
the northeast coast of Australasia, towards
New Guinea, and very far exceed in length,
any Chain of fsecondary mountains in Europe.
A calcarious concreted sand rock has been
found to exist in Australasia throughout
space of no less than twenty-five degrees of
latitude; and an equal extent of longitude on
the southern, west and northwest coasts.

THE REVOLUTION OF A YEAR.


"rhese regular returning aspects OF ma
ture which divide mans time into equal
parts, and which he has only to number as
they succeed each other, like the !ettercd
stones erected on the sides of our roads, TO
inform the traveller what space Of ground
he has traversed, serve to give notice to the
passenger through human life, how tar he


has proceeded in his path 70 the grave.-----
Most pointed are the marks, most torcible
are the momentos of their expiration. They
| irresistbly rouse our attention to the wings
of time and force us to take notice OF his
fight Nature signifies it to us by no faint


intimations; she proclaims it with loud


voice-she paints it in strong colours. he
monitor must and will be heard Negeta-


ton starts from the ground-a green rcsur-


rection surprises the eve--thc lear fades and
| falls-thc forest is stripped-the shower Is
| frozen--and the waters are fettered TO spur
to his duties irresolute and procrastinatng


man This repeated proclamation OF nature
to mankind, which revolving seasons sue
cessively utter, that their years are rolling
swiftly, once in every year 1t is their Gus
tom to echo. Once in every year they tell
one another what nature tells them more
than once---that those longest periods OF
their time are passing rapidly from them
another of those years Of which only few
make up the life of man, is become part
of the irrevocable past, A year is season
of magnitude i'll the little life ef man. II IS
an ample stride to the tomb. 4 few more
strides viii bring US all thither''


From a publication entitled "Some ac-
count of the Armenian Christians at Con-
stantnople, by late Chaplain to the British
EmbasSv,'' = is taken the annexed description
of the marriage ceremony OF the .irmenians


In their marriages they are very precise,
not only enforcing the canon of consanyuini-
ty which our church enjoins, but many 9TH
ers which our church does not. A second
marriage is allowed to the laitv, but the
third brings with it a scandal that no Arme-
nian will venture te incur. They are in all
things, anxious to maintain the fitness and
| propriety of things: widows are enjoined to
unite themselves to widowers only, and spin


sters to bachelors. AS the nation is really


Asiatic, their notions Of female proprlety


are all founded in oriental feelings. Their


women are kept in state OF severe seclu


sion and the parties to be married never
see each other perhaps, till they meet at the


marriage ceremony. There are certain ex-
perienced females, whose exclusive profess
sion it is, to make matches, and who are SO


numerous as to form, like all bodies of pco-


pie of the same pursuits in the East, kind


Of corporation 70 every family, one Of


these has access and when it is deemed pru-


dent or desirable by her friends, that fe-


male should marry, this person is commits
stoned to look out for suitable match, and


never fails to find one. was invited to the


wedding Of young lady of one of the first
{ Armenian families in Pera, whose match
was made in this wav, and who was assur-
ed, had never seen the man she was going tc
, marry. We went about eight O'Clock in the


evening, and found the house lighted up and
: full of the lady's friends among whom


where the priest and his wife, very plain
simple looking people. We passed through


several anterooms, IN which were groups OF


people, and we're finally ushe"ed into an in
side chamber, round which was tivan Or
long sofa, against the wall. On the diyan
; was number of Armenian ladies' sitting
, cross legged, two or three deep, and close
together; and at the far corner sat a still
motonless form. like bust in niche, COW
cred with rich veil, glittcring with gold
which hung down on all sides, so AS entirely
. to conceal the figure which stood beneath it


This bust was the pride Across the middle


of the room was line Of men standing, two


or three deep, gazing in silence on the bride


Out of Complaisance to our Frank customs,


chairs were brought for our accommodation


and placed inside the line of men ON those
we both sat down, and continued for a long
{ time, to gaze in silence also. The bride now
for the first time, permitted her veil to be
raised but it was Immediately again let fall
The short glimpse, however, showed us a
Slight figure and pale face, with AN express
sion exceedingly joyless and pensivc. She


formed strong contrast tn the ladies OH the
. divan, who, tho silent or speaking in whisp-
ers, were in high SPLITS. They were all
distinguished by glttering coronets of gold
. and diamonds, placed on the crown of the
!. head. from whence their hair hung down in
. the most beautiful and extraordinary profu-
e sion, n,-sweeping the divan on which they
were sitting. Their faces in general were


lovely, their manners very modest, but very
, affabe, and no one was veiled or reserved,
c but the bride. Refreshments were handed
{ to us by two of the young ladies. who step
d ped from the dvan for the purpose. They
consisted of little glasses of red rosolio follow
if ed by a spoonful of a sweet, white, consist
= ent syrup, like flour and honey, and wash
Il

GormondizMg.-On Monday last, in this
village, man, upon banter. undertook to
eat, within an hour, one hundred round
ciums! They were to be roasted for him,
and he was ts take them out of the shells
himself. He despatched batch of 80 in 5
minutes, and proceeded with the othersuu.
til he had swallowed II, when the 18th
went and come, like the old wofnan's soap
However. he at length disposed of that and
another, when he gave up the job, having
actually devoured 79! And they were ofno
mean sizc..afor the meat one, which IVES
fair sample of the lot, was found to weigh 2
ounces: making the quantity taken down BY
the man. batting trifle for wastage, nine
hounds and fourteen ounces.

My dear Mrs. Decatur:


The re-assembling OF the honorable Con-

your esteemed favor of June last, in which
you requested me TO state such information
relative to the burning of the Philadelphia,
in the harbor of 'Frpoli, as / may possess,
in aid of your claim on our country, for the
success of that gallant enterprise, so ably
and honorably performed by your late hus-
band.


regret that my limited abilities dsqual-
lty me from pourtraying in those glowing
colours of which that act is susceptible, the
gallantry and perseverance with which it
was performed by my late friend.
You state that your late husband had Civ.
EN- you to understand that the project OF
burning that frigate, at her moorings, and
thereby removing serious mpediment to
the future operations of the squadl Oh against
'Iripoli, originated with him. This under :
standing was perfectly correct--it did orr
slnate with your late husband, and he first
volunteered himself to carry it into effect;
and asked the permission of Commodore
preble, Oft Iripoli, (on first discovering the

II good one.--The following story has re-
Gently been related tous-the author youch-
ing for its correctness "A gentleman of re-
spectacle appearance, about forty years of
age recently arrived at the village of Utica,
where he had some business to transact pre-
paratory to departing for the west. BY
some concession OF his own, or by his out
ward demeanor, which in such cases is e.
Qually as we'll understood, he was ascertain
ed to be modern C9lebs. in search of a
wife, one of your antiquated bachelors, tir-
ed of single blessedness, who at last collect
ed sufficient courage to SO out among the
fair daughters Of the land to find helpmate.
The information was not long in coming to
the ears of "a frail sister," whom nature
had endowed with liberal share of person
al charms, and who resolved to turn the af-
fair to a good account. To effect her object


she took passage for the west, in the same
boat with our wandering Benedict, in the
character of rich young widow, who hat
formerly resided at Buffalo, whittier she
wa. proceeding to settle some business q
her late husband. But little time had elaps
ed before all opportunity presented itself TO
m interview with him, which resulted in


complete disclosure on her part OF passio


she had conceived FOR him when she frs
came into his presence. our gentleman had


little romance in his ideas of love and court
ship; yet, the idea of falling in love on ca
nal boat, caused a little doubt in his mnc
which induced him to ask how much 1t wa
possible "that young and beautiful femal
should on so short an acquaintance, be ena
incurred with one so far her superior j


years." $50 1t is" said she-clted prece
dents to show that the mischievous littl
rogue Cupid, had proceeded by smila
means-and with affected pious resignation
she said-"matches are made in heaven.
Without entering minutely into the cour'
ship that followed, it is sufficient to say ths
her reasons were conclusive: they banishe
all doubts from his mind, and matrimon
was intended as the result. On arriving {
Black Rock. they agreed to go on shore an
celebrate the .nuptials. She suggested tn
;.!ea, however, that he had better stop, an

It is stated in western paper that in or
der to prevent depreciation in the circnla-
ton of the Nashville Bank notes, the House
Of Representatives of Tennessee have pass
ed bill making the notes of the Nashville
Bank. receivable at the new bank and its
agencies, for calls up to January 1928. and
for the revenue Of the present year, when
the collecting officers shall swear they re-
ceved them for taxes before hearing Of the
suspension. Itis expected the bill Will pass
the Senate.

A letter from Washington says "Mrs Decatur
has again presented her claims to Congress, for
an allowance to be made to her, for the destruc
ton of the frigate Philadelphia, by her late hus-
band, in the hsrbor of Trpoli, in 1904" We
have seen a pamphlet of 62 pages, containing
the documents published BY Mrs. Decatur, rcla-
tive to this claim, and think that the lady has
made out fair case, and to be justly entitled to
the benevolence of a liberal and high minded
Legislature. B9st. Centina.

full articles.headline: PN x sylTtJ .a.sasy.
full articles.article:
To induce the numerous Correspondents
Of the Saturday Evening Post aud others to
furnish original essays and metrical compo-
sitions particularly calculated to enrich the
columns Of the Casket for 1927, the publish
crs have been induced 10 oFcrthe following
rewards.


/. The Caskct for 1926, 1927 and 1923
embellished with numerous engravlngs, and
handsomely bound in rich extra binding,
for the best Essay, in prose, OF moderate
length


.. The Casket for three years, COM
mencing with the volume just finished,
bound in the same superb manner, for the
best American tale, of moderate length.


3. The Caskct for three years, commenc.
ing as above. bound in superb STYLE for the
best Biography of American character, male
or female


a. The Casket for years. or years
subscription to the Saturday Evening Post,
for the 5est metrical composition, not ex-
ceeding sixty lines.
One years subscription to the Casket,
for 1927, will be awarded to each of the Sc.
co'ld best articles in either OF the above de-
partmcnts.


The articles must be addressed to .4tkm-
son u .flerander, Philadelphia, post pad,
and handed in by the first of March next,
when they will undergo the inspection Of
three Literary gentlemen Of this city. and
the awards be distributed with fairness and
impartiality.


Editors throughout the Union friendly to
American Literature, will please to give
this notice two or three insertions.

full articles.headline: The priest vas now called forward to per-
full articles.article:
The priest vas now called forward to per-
torn another important ceremony. low
table was placed near the nuptal taper =
it was covered with white cloth or napkin,
and the priest sat down at one end, attended
by another Armenian who was not priest,
to say responses. He took out OF his bosom
a small cruci6x, and waving it several times
in the air over the table, uttered henedic-
ton; he then began prayer, and conciuoed
with psalm, accompanied by his assistant
in very dissonant and nasal tone. When
the psalm was over, we were very curious to
see what was under the cloth. 1t was lifted
slowly up, and large rich shawl appeared
on the table, which was Immediately taken
and tremendously wrapped round the pride.
This was considered one of the most lmpor-
tant parts OF the ceremony, and called bless
ing the nuptial. Wenow took our leave and
were invited to come again on the morrow,
when the bride was to be conveyed to the
bridegroom, who was all this time at Gala
to, a distant part of the town, & never SUIT
fered to approach the house. The next day
the lady was led down in the same dress she
wore the day before, and i'll addition to the
ample veil, the eonsecrated shawl was
wrapped round her in such way as abso-
lutely to envelope her


All aruba or Turkish coach drawn by buff
faoes. was waiting at the door; this consist
ed of long platform of boards laid upon 4
wheels, and surmounted with gaudy cano-
py Of wood, carved and gilt. Into this the
bride was lifted, wrapped up, like a child in
swaddling clothes going to be christened.-


Her female friends, including the priests
wife. to the number of ten or twelve. sat
round her,-so as effectualy to conceal her
person. The nuptial candle was borne on
the shoulder of a boy who walked before ;
and in this way the procession slowly moved
to Galato, to the house of her husband. when
for the first time, he was permitted to see
her face. The final marriage ceremony did
not take place till three days after, at which
no strangers We're admitted.o

gate Amazon, had also arrived at Rio, the
latter on the 18TH of October. in " days
from New York. The United States ship
Boston arrived a. Monte Video on the 18th
of October; and the Brazilian Admiral
Rodriguez, with four frigates from cruise


The blockade of the river is still strictly
maintained. Several American vessels have
been sent into Montevideo, by the blockading
squadron, and the brig Homer from Bucnos
Ayres to Santos, is detained at the latter
place for having loaded few months since az
Rio. and violated the blockade.

full articles.article:
Poultry.-We are told that fowls are fatter and
more abundant this season than usual The
cause assigned is this THE swarms CT grass.
hoppers which destroyed the crops and desolas.
ed the fields of the husbandman, furnished a,
abundance of rich food for the fowls thus v.i.
tying the old provcrb,-" 1t is an i'll wind tha.
blows nobody good" One man in plainfeld bas
brought more than three thousand pounds Of
poultry to this market and great quantitie,h have
been sold by others.

full articles.headline:
SOUTH AMERICA.

DEFEAT OF THE BRAZILIANs
full articles.article:
DEFEAT OF THE BRAZlLIANS.


A letter from the Coast of Brazil has lust
reached us, which contains information I'M
pleasant to the cause of the Emperor. 1t is
dated Santos September 26tlf, and to this ef-
feet:


"There has been a serious conflict between
the Bucnos Avrean troops, and the Brazil
ians, near Montevideo. in which the latter
we're defeated with the loss, it is here cur
rentIy reported, of seventeen hundred pris-
oners, the number of killed and wounded not
mentioned; but, as the contest is supposed
to have been a sangunary one, the loss
must have been excessive.


General .Ilparcz is marching with a
sufficient army for RIO Grande, and the i'm
preston prevails among several well inform
ed and intelligent political men, intimately
acquainted with the defences of the country,
and the disposable force under the Brazil
ians, that the Province will be abandoned
to the Bnenos Ayreans without much oppo-
sition. Should this event take place, | APP
prehend that our Brazilian friends will intl
some difficulty about jerked BERT, in addition
to their other troubles, as it is At that place
they obtain their principal supply, and the
Buenos Ayreans have determined, as mat
ter Of policy, to suspend the preparation of
peer, ana ucVCte tnelr entire energies TO the
successful prosecution of the war.


"There is now no doubt that Admiral
Brown, of whose exploits and unexampled
bravery you must have heard frequently,
has taken command of the Chilian Squadron,
and is daily, might more properly say
hourly looked for on the Coast. AS this
place lies so conveniently to the mouth OF
of the LA Plata, and affords good harbour
and facilities for operations against the Bra
zllians, Admiral Brown will in all probabili-
ty make his first demonstration here. It's
possession is a matter Of the first Importance
to Buenos Ayres, should her Military views
extend really to the occupation of Ric
Grande, and its loss to Brazil, could only be
felt once, and that forever"


"Santos may bc considered point d d'appui
OF much interest, and whether the Brazil.
ians held it in this estimation or not, ] am
uncertain; but of one thing / feel pretty
confident that were it in the hands of Brown


it's Importance to the trade and military de-
signs of Brazil would be most strikingly ex.
emplihed."


The United States ships BrQndy4pine ant
Vincennes arrived at Rio Janeiro on the 28tl


of October, all ON board we'll; lost by death


sailing master Malbone and seaman. 1t i
: considered a remarkable circumstance tina


these two vessels sailed SO we'll togethe
that an hour was not lost in the whole ru,
from the United States to Rio, by eitherves

All these birds have practice OF cunnlnsiy.
stealing from one another, during the .iule oi
nest building, the materials Of which they
are constructed. They differ from the king
nenpuin in these particulars, and also in hav-
mo nests. which are sometimes in the SIDES
of tussac mounds, but generally on the siues
of hill. and are composed OF teW SUCKS
and stones -


The following description which Capt W.
gives of his situation when entangled IN the
ice, presents an interesting and 1eaftui
picture of the perils OF polar Navigation.
The two vessels under his command the one
a brig. the other cutter, SAILING south from
the Falkland Islands in November, became
completely surrounded with Az ice islands,
from which there was no esress


ain the morning of the 18th we had clos
ed with large ice island, and IN spite OF
all our cndeavors to avoid it, we Continued
approaching. At 10 o'clock it was within
two ships length, and from its peculiar
shape threatened TO overwhelm us; tor the
upper part OF the side nearest TO us, which
was about 1870 feet high, projected SO much
as would have admitted the briggs mast COM
ing in contract with it underneath, and TINS
overhangns part was cracked from the top
down TO the water line. From both vessels
being unavoidably together, both were ike
ly to suffer by the same accident AN our
attempts to hcave the vessels out OF the
course of this danger was in vain, out they
had the good effect of occupying the crews
and thus Withdrawing their ATTENTION from
their perilous situation. Within half All hour
had the appalling sight OF the oVerhalsins
mass Immediately over the quater oecK,
with the fearful sensation that, it our mast
came in contact with it, the projecting part
would fall upon us and sink both vessels.
Our escape was caused solely by our having
large floe piece of ice between us and the
ice island. which prevented our mast from
touching it. The packed ice separated to
each side. and we passed round the north
corner. The rolling of this island In its
passage had produced slackness in the 9TH
er ice, of which was determined TO take
advantage for returning, and so cast oil the
cutter" In this manner the vessels escap-
ed the danger.


The following, translated from French
work by correspondent OF the Charicston
Courier, is an excellent satire upon the pleas
ures Of the appetite.


PIGS EARS.


The Sage who enlightens the world and
devotes his days and nights to the improve
ment OF mankind, dies frequently OF want, IN
an obscure garret-while vile buftoons, who
currupt manners, and the dangerous Cate
rers tor the glutton, are enriched, caressed
and honored. Such was the cook of Marx
Antony, who became Governor OF city, tor
having roasted a young wild boar. to suit
the taste of that incorporate General. Such
was he, who prepared for Charles the 5th,
.io lEo tn m


This famous monarch, after the fatgues
Of the chase, near Valladolid, went to dine
with neighboring Lord, Having been APP
prised of the intended courtesy of his sove
reign, the host studied to have prepared fol
him, a repast equally splendid and singular
When the Prince had dined, he praised We.
~ much the meats and avowed frankly
that the greatest part of them were perfect
ly new to him. The Nobleman who hat
entertained the Spanish King, replied tina
the animals that had supplied the feast wer,
not only very rare, but that they were al
still alive. He then took the Monarch int
neighboring apartment, and pointed out tt
him, in large pasture, the rare birds which
he had been eating. This was a troup O
pigs without ears and without tails; ans
these tails and ears, with the aid of potatoes
reduced to -four, had been dressed with 81
much art that they resembled fowls, venison
turbot, salmon, carp, eels, and almes, every
thing.


The Emperor relished particularly tn,
tails of the pigs, without ears, which he tool
to be the pike and eel of Tartary-indeed
he was so satisfied with this strange repast
that he complimented the cook in person
upon his profound skill in the art OF sauce
and frica,ees. The king did not confne hi
r.. y 30
the cook with tract Of land; thus his disl
of pigs ears and tails enabled him to live th
rest of his life in secure abundance, muel
happier than the grandee of Spain, who's
kitchen fire he had kindled wish such shin
ing success.

spectacle appearance, about forty years o
age recently arrived at the village of Utica

only riding stick 45 years ago, was now aus.
"a feet high, and feet in diameter about foot
from the ground, where it was chopped off,

quarts of molasses into keg of ten gallons
cool water. Boil two OF. allspice, two o.
ginger, two OF. hops. and half pint ofIndiau
meal, in tive or three quarts of water. abou.
an hour-strain it into the kcs while hot, add

full articles.headline: Mrs. Susan Decatur.
full articles.article:
NoTE:-Commodore Stewart was in the SQUAD
ron when the Philadelphia was re.captured. n.
commanded the brig Syrcn, which vessel was en-.
gagged IN the expedition: He was the senior ,f
ticer, and had also volunteered his services; and
the preference was given to Commodore Decs
tur because he had been the first to propose IL


and IN consequence OF It, he was promoted over
the heads Of Stewart, Hull, Chauncy, and many
others of the most distinguished officers in the
Navy, who all admitted that he had dcscredh

his command. The CommanJ.,


thought it too hazardous to he sgoant
that way, but promised your late easo b.. IN
that u should be carried into effect ff.Nsua on
proper occasion, and that he should bs 4.
executive officer when it was done. Il He
accordingly effected in the ketch Intrssi, va,
oy your husband and seventy voh,n,sppsw.
from the schooner he commanded. tlseefs a. s.
hazard, not only of life or liberty bu. sIeat
OF reputation also, and in the season .nat
perilous in approaching that coast mos. ~,
recollection of the difficulties and d.,iae iae
he had to encounter in that exnedii;onse's
which was an eye witness, excit.s ot
and more my admiration of his r.l.aos mofs
and enterprise; and although the respl, spl,'hy shy5
lustre throughout Europe over the sneu
ican character, and excited an unnar,nV unst, ~,
emulation in the squadron, in our ,"Sea conn,e
alone is where 1t has never been dulv az!
mated, or properly understood. Co,ra ''
and great force alone could not have efFso,sss
1t. 1t was necessary not only to nnt y,
smallest possible force to hazard but its .0. a.e
cess depended upon very small force hs.N saV'
used; the genius and mental resources n, sS
execu iv officer could alone compepsa,e W.. ~.
want of force and numbers. To these Ss
mands your late husband was found hlI,,
adequate; and hence the brilliant res,,,,
The frigate was completely DESTROYED in tbo
midst OF the enemy, and his retreat effec,.s
without the loss of man
Accept, my dear madam, the assuran,.
of my highest respect and esteem.


CHAS. STEWART.
Captain u. S. NAVY

let her proceed to Buffalo, invite her friends.
purchase some articles Of clothing, for her
self and him. and return. TO bring his
clothing back, it was necessary to take a
long his trunk, containing his money, pa
pers, &c. To this he willingly consented;
she departed on her mission, and he took
lodgings at a hotel to await her return. Hav-
ing waited beyond the appointed time he
grew impatient, and repaired to Buffalo,
where he soon ascertaincd that his intended,
in company with a goodly portion OF his
worldly goods, had taken passage in stage,
and left him to regret his folly.

plaCe 10Y UaVlIlb tOhutu tcW oiAiSS a.
Rio, and violated the blockade.


Cotton 17anufacturc.-It is stated by Mr..
Rush in his report, that the cotton manu-
factories of the United States work up fuli
one fourth part OF the whole crop OF raw
cotton raised in the Southern and Western
States. As this statement is founded on da-
ta that cannot deceive, we may take It with
an unusual degree of certainty. OF all the
statistical facts which lately have come un-
der our observation, we must be permitted
to say this is the most gratifying. Only
let us look back upon our internal industry
for the last 10 years. Iu 1916 we were but
in the commencement. but now our cotton
fabrics can compete with the English. If,
in the short space OF ten years, we have ris-
en- to the consumption of Of our whole raw
cotton crop, what may we not expect from
the succeeding ten? When did nation
possess such prospect as the United States?
In very few years, the whole cotton crop
of the South will be worked up at the North
and East One portion of the country will
supply the other with raw productions, and
that in return with manufactured. Within
the limits of the Republic we have every
variety Of soil and climate. We can pro-
duce every thing within ourselves tits this
peculiar character osthe country that will
become the great bend Of union. A recipro-
cation OF benefits will unite the South, the
West. and the East, in one feeling and one
interest. We shall then be beyond the com.
mercial vicissitudes of Europe. Our depen-
lence for every manufacture will be placed
OH our own artisans. This happy period is
fast approaching, and neither the arts of for
eign or secret enemies can prevent its ac.
complishment.


The National Journal announces that the
Convention between the United States and
England. making provision for compensating
the owners Of fprivate property taken from
the United States after the close Of the late
war with Great Britain, has been ratified
by the President and Senate. The prompt
ness with which this Convention was decid-
ed on in the Senate, confirms the opinion
that it provides for an ample restitution to
those Of our citizens whose property had
been taken from them subsequent to the
war, and that it does them justice, and will
give satisfaction to all the claimants.

| The York {Penn,) Gazette states, that
| from the surveys already made, it is asccr-
tanned to be impracticable to construct q
continuous Canal through Pennsylvania, con-
meeting the eastern and western waters; and
that the Canal Commissioners will report
in favor of adopting the Jnnata route, inn
proving the navigation of that river, by ca
nails or otherwise, as high up as feasible, and
then passing to the hlleghany river by
means of railway.


| IT is calculated that more than one hun
dred and seventy volcanoes are at present
in activity on this land, and there is reason
to believe that there are at least as many
and probably greater number beneath the
sea- Captain King in his late survey of
Australasia, sailed along continued line OF
Coral Ttel IOr seven nunureu mNeS, IAlcr-
ruptsd only by few intervals not exceed
ing thirty miles. These reefs stretch from
the northeast coast of Australasia, towards
New Guinea, and very far exceed in length,
any Chain of fsecondary mountains in Europe.
A calcarious concreted sand rock has been
found to exist in Australasia throughout
space of no less than twenty-five degrees of
latitude; and an equal extent of longitude on
the southern, west and northwest coasts.

has again presented her claims to Congress, for

made out fair case, and to be justly entitled to
the benevolence of a liberal and high minded
Legislature, Centinel

Mrs. Decatur.


| BoydcntoUn, Dec. 18th, 1896
| My dear Mrs. Decatur:


| The re-assemblng OF the honorable Con-
| gress of the United States, renders il peces

Lockh't Observatory.
THE REVOLUTION OF A YEAR.


"rhese regular returning aspects OF ma
ture which divide mans time into equal
parts, and which he has only to number as
they succeed each other, like the !ettercd
stones erected on the sides of our roads, TO
inform the traveller what space Of ground
he has traversed, serve to give notice to the
passenger through human life, how tar he


has proceeded in his path 70 the grave.-----
Most pointed are the marks, most torcible
are the momentos of their expiration. They
| irresistbly rouse our attention to the wings
of time and force us to take notice OF his
fight Nature signifies it to us by no faint


intimations; she proclaims it with loud


voice-she paints it in strong colours. he
monitor must and will be heard Negeta-


ton starts from the ground-a green rcsur-


rection surprises the eve--thc lear fades and
| falls-thc forest is stripped-the shower Is
| frozen--and the waters are fettered TO spur
to his duties irresolute and procrastinatng


man This repeated proclamation OF nature
to mankind, which revolving seasons sue
cessively utter, that their years are rolling
swiftly, once in every year 1t is their Gus
tom to echo. Once in every year they tell
one another what nature tells them more
than once---that those longest periods OF
their time are passing rapidly from them
another of those years Of which only few
make up the life of man, is become part
of the irrevocable past, A year is season
of magnitude i'll the little life ef man. II IS
an ample stride to the tomb. 4 few more
strides viii bring US all thither''


From a publication entitled "Some ac-
count of the Armenian Christians at Con-
stantnople, by late Chaplain to the British
EmbasSv,'' = is taken the annexed description
of the marriage ceremony OF the .irmenians


In their marriages they are very precise,
not only enforcing the canon of consanyuini-
ty which our church enjoins, but many 9TH
ers which our church does not. A second
marriage is allowed to the laitv, but the
third brings with it a scandal that no Arme-
nian will venture te incur. They are in all
things, anxious to maintain the fitness and
| propriety of things: widows are enjoined to
unite themselves to widowers only, and spin


sters to bachelors. AS the nation is really


Asiatic, their notions Of female proprlety


are all founded in oriental feelings. Their


women are kept in state OF severe seclu


sion and the parties to be married never
see each other perhaps, till they meet at the


marriage ceremony. There are certain ex-
perienced females, whose exclusive profess
sion it is, to make matches, and who are SO


numerous as to form, like all bodies of pco-


pie of the same pursuits in the East, kind


Of corporation 70 every family, one Of


these has access and when it is deemed pru-


dent or desirable by her friends, that fe-


male should marry, this person is commits
stoned to look out for suitable match, and


never fails to find one. was invited to the


wedding Of young lady of one of the first
{ Armenian families in Pera, whose match
was made in this wav, and who was assur-
ed, had never seen the man she was going tc
, marry. We went about eight O'Clock in the


evening, and found the house lighted up and
: full of the lady's friends among whom


where the priest and his wife, very plain
simple looking people. We passed through


several anterooms, IN which were groups OF


people, and we're finally ushe"ed into an in
side chamber, round which was tivan Or
long sofa, against the wall. On the diyan
; was number of Armenian ladies' sitting
, cross legged, two or three deep, and close
together; and at the far corner sat a still
motonless form. like bust in niche, COW
cred with rich veil, glittcring with gold
which hung down on all sides, so AS entirely
. to conceal the figure which stood beneath it


This bust was the pride Across the middle


of the room was line Of men standing, two


or three deep, gazing in silence on the bride


Out of Complaisance to our Frank customs,


chairs were brought for our accommodation


and placed inside the line of men ON those
we both sat down, and continued for a long
{ time, to gaze in silence also. The bride now
for the first time, permitted her veil to be
raised but it was Immediately again let fall
The short glimpse, however, showed us a
Slight figure and pale face, with AN express
sion exceedingly joyless and pensivc. She


formed strong contrast tn the ladies OH the
. divan, who, tho silent or speaking in whisp-
ers, were in high SPLITS. They were all
distinguished by glttering coronets of gold
. and diamonds, placed on the crown of the
!. head. from whence their hair hung down in
. the most beautiful and extraordinary profu-
e sion, n,-sweeping the divan on which they
were sitting. Their faces in general were


lovely, their manners very modest, but very
, affabe, and no one was veiled or reserved,
c but the bride. Refreshments were handed
{ to us by two of the young ladies. who step
d ped from the dvan for the purpose. They
consisted of little glasses of red rosolio follow
if ed by a spoonful of a sweet, white, consist
= ent syrup, like flour and honey, and wash
Il

7ert and Comment. What man is there Of
you, when, if his son ask bread, will give him .
stone" Matthew vii. 9. The Legislature o.
Virginia has appointed committee to report ci
the expediency Of erecting marble monument
to the memory Of the late venerated Thomas
Jefferson

GormondizMg.-On Monday last, in this
village, man, upon banter. undertook to
eat, within an hour, one hundred round
ciums! They were to be roasted for him,
and he was ts take them out of the shells
himself. He despatched batch of 80 in 5
minutes, and proceeded with the othersuu.
til he had swallowed II, when the 18th
went and come, like the old wofnan's soap
However. he at length disposed of that and
another, when he gave up the job, having
actually devoured 79! And they were ofno
mean sizc..afor the meat one, which IVES
fair sample of the lot, was found to weigh 2
ounces: making the quantity taken down BY
the man. batting trifle for wastage, nine
hounds and fourteen ounces.

Copy of letter from Commodore Stewart tc
Mrs Decatur.


BoydcntoYaa, Dec. 18th, 1926.
full articles.article:
Copy of letter from Commodore Stewart to


Mrs. Decatur.


BoydentoUn, Dec. 18th, 1926.


My dear Mrs. Decatur:


The re-assembling OF the honorable Con-
gress of the United States. renders it neces
sary that should no longer delay answering
your esteemed favor of June last, in which
you requested me TO state such information
relative to the burning of the Philadelphia,
in the harbor of 'Frpoli, as / may possess,
in aid of your claim on our country, for the
success of that gallant enterprise, so ably
and honorably performed by your late hus-
band.


regret that my limited abilities dsqual-
lty me from pourtraying in those glowing
colours of which that act is susceptible, the
gallantry and perseverance with which it
was performed by my late friend.
You state that your late husband had Civ.
EN- you to understand that the project OF
burning that frigate, at her moorings, and
thereby removing serious mpediment to
the future operations of the squadl Oh against
'Iripoli, originated with him. This under :
standing was perfectly correct--it did orr
slnate with your late husband, and he first
volunteered himself to carry it into effect;
and asked the permission of Commodore
preble, Oft Iripoli, (on first discovering the
| frigate was lost to the squadron to effect it
with the schooner Enterprise. then under

II am heartily glad to meet you here al

II good one.--The following story has re-
Gently been related tous-the author youch-
ing for its correctness "A gentleman of re-
spectacle appearance, about forty years of
age recently arrived at the village of Utica,
where he had some business to transact pre-
paratory to departing for the west. BY
some concession OF his own, or by his out
ward demeanor, which in such cases is e.
Qually as we'll understood, he was ascertain
ed to be modern C9lebs. in search of a
wife, one of your antiquated bachelors, tir-
ed of single blessedness, who at last collect
ed sufficient courage to SO out among the
fair daughters Of the land to find helpmate.
The information was not long in coming to
the ears of "a frail sister," whom nature
had endowed with liberal share of person
al charms, and who resolved to turn the af-
fair to a good account. To effect her object


she took passage for the west, in the same
boat with our wandering Benedict, in the
character of rich young widow, who hat
formerly resided at Buffalo, whittier she
wa. proceeding to settle some business q
her late husband. But little time had elaps
ed before all opportunity presented itself TO
m interview with him, which resulted in


complete disclosure on her part OF passio


she had conceived FOR him when she frs
came into his presence. our gentleman had


little romance in his ideas of love and court
ship; yet, the idea of falling in love on ca
nal boat, caused a little doubt in his mnc
which induced him to ask how much 1t wa
possible "that young and beautiful femal
should on so short an acquaintance, be ena
incurred with one so far her superior j


years." $50 1t is" said she-clted prece
dents to show that the mischievous littl
rogue Cupid, had proceeded by smila
means-and with affected pious resignation
she said-"matches are made in heaven.
Without entering minutely into the cour'
ship that followed, it is sufficient to say ths
her reasons were conclusive: they banishe
all doubts from his mind, and matrimon
was intended as the result. On arriving {
Black Rock. they agreed to go on shore an
celebrate the .nuptials. She suggested tn
;.!ea, however, that he had better stop, an

It is stated in western paper that in or
der to prevent depreciation in the circnla-
ton of the Nashville Bank notes, the House
Of Representatives of Tennessee have pass
ed bill making the notes of the Nashville
Bank. receivable at the new bank and its
agencies, for calls up to January 1928. and
for the revenue Of the present year, when
the collecting officers shall swear they re-
ceved them for taxes before hearing Of the
suspension. Itis expected the bill Will pass
the Senate.

A letter from Washington says "Mrs Decatur
has again presented her claims to Congress, for
an allowance to be made to her, for the destruc
ton of the frigate Philadelphia, by her late hus-
band, in the hsrbor of Trpoli, in 1904" We
have seen a pamphlet of 62 pages, containing
the documents published BY Mrs. Decatur, rcla-
tive to this claim, and think that the lady has
made out fair case, and to be justly entitled to
the benevolence of a liberal and high minded
Legislature. B9st. Centina.
